data.text: Contents
Introduction
The aim of this policy is to ensure clear standards are in place for all commercial sponsorship and advertising within the Trust.

The role of the communications and engagement team is to ensure all communications and marketing activity puts patients at the heart of our organisation and supports the delivery of excellent care and better health for our communities so that patients and commissioners choose us as their provider of choice.

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is not opposed to the principle of accepting sponsorship for services, events or advertising with the hospital or Trust publications, if it is deemed to benefit the Trust.
Advertising displayed anywhere in the hospitals or in any publications must however, reflect our core values;
Excellent Compassionate Respectful
Scope

The purpose of this document is to provide guidance to staff and third party organisations regarding allowances for advertising and sponsorship in suitable situations and circumstances. All adverts and sponsorship must comply with relevant regulations and the basic principles of advertising – legal, decent, honest and truthful.
The development and implementation of this policy will:
reassure patients and potential patients
protect and guide staff, and
reduce corporate risk to the trust resulting from compliance with relevant national policy guidance (e.g. Commercial Sponsorship: Ethical Standards for the NHS – Department of Health, 2000)
Definitions

table_items.text: For the purposes of this policy, commercial sponsorship is defined as “NHS funding from an external source, including funding of all or part of the costs of a member of staff, NHS research, staff, training, pharmaceuticals, equipment, meeting rooms, costs associated with meetings, meals, gifts, hospitality, hotel and transport costs (including trips abroad), provision of free services (speakers), buildings or premises” as well as funding for advertising (see below).

For the purposes of this policy, advertising refers to any promotional materials displayed within the Trust or its publications for organisations other than the Trust itself where the Trust receives some financial or other benefit (e.g. payment in kind). This includes patient information, leaflets, plasma screens, display advertising, advertisements surrounding maps and notice boards, online advertising and display boards (e.g. billboards) located within the Trust estate.

For the purposes of this policy, this refers to materials intended to provide factual and impartial information, advice and guidance about health conditions (e.g. factual information about the diagnosis and treatment of specific conditions) and the services of the Trust (e.g. factual information about directions and car parking arrangements).

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities (i.e. Medicines Committees) Duties Are:
Trust Board

The trust board is ultimately responsible for the effective running of the organisation in accordance with relevant legislation and guidance. Monitoring of the implementation of this policy will provide assurance to the trust board that effective organisational controls are in place for commercial sponsorship and advertising.
Executive team

The executive team is responsible for oversight of this policy on behalf of the board. It will also receive reports by exception on any commercial sponsorship or advertising activities in the name of the trust that do not comply with this policy
Audit Committee
The audit committee reviews risk, control and assurance on behalf of the board, and will seek such assurance as it requires on behalf of the board in relation to the implementation of this policy
Estates board
The estates board is responsible for monitoring compliance with the policy – materials, health and safety
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)
Duties Are:
Chief Executive is responsible for:

Ensuring that the arrangements in support of policy are fully implemented through inclusion in Clinical Directorate Performance Reviews. In order for this responsibility to be effectively discharged, Executive Directors and senior colleagues will have specific delegated responsibility to support the Chief Executive in this process.
Chief finance officer

All contracts for advertising or sponsorship will be managed by the chief finance officer to ensure that best terms are negotiated, the Standing Financial instructions (SFIs) are not breached and to ensure continuity and consistency
Associate Director of communications and engagement

The Associate Director of communications and engagement will review, approve, reject or sign off all advertising copy before any material is sent for printing or before any advertisement is displayed in any part of the hospital
Communications and engagement team

Where departments are approached directly for sponsorship and advertising purposes, or where they are holding an event which requires sponsorship, the department must inform the communications and engagement team before approaching organisations. It may be necessary to request reference from existing clients.
Sponsorship and advertising

Sponsorship and selling advertising space are more straightforward transactions than other communications partnerships. For example on patient information leaflets, on patient information screens or in other Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust owned spaces.

The public will make assumptions about who benefits most from these transactions, and about whether MSE is choosing to endorse the activity or values of the sponsor or advertiser. For these reasons some consideration outlined below must be undertaken prior to any sponsored activities or selling of advertising space.
Sponsorship refers to an arrangement where the NHS receives financial support or support-in-kind in return for the rights to public association with an activity or property.
For example, a local company sponsoring an NHS staff newsletter or staff awards ceremony.
Points to consider:

NHS organisations may enter into commercial sponsorship arrangements. However, they (as with other communications partnerships) should avoid entering into arrangements with organisations perceived to be in conflict with health, for example tobacco and alcohol companies, specific ‘no win, no fee' advertising, personal injury lawyers and claims management companies.

NHS organisations need to ensure they are not put under any undue obligation to a sponsor (or that they become open to the accusation), that core business functions are not affected and that they remain impartial.

In every situation a written contract must be put in place detailing what the company expects from the Trust and what the Trust expects from the company. Once produced this needs to be signed off in accordance with the Trust's standing orders and standing financial instructions.
The sponsor's support should be seen as adding significant benefit to an existing health promotion messages, campaign or event.

There should be no overt commercial advantage to the sponsor in terms of the direct sale of products or brands as a result of their association with the NHS. Their involvement should be seen as secondary to the aims of the NHS.

The risks of being overly dependent on funding for a project include the possibility that the sponsor withdraws support. Organisations should consider how the project would be funded if this happened.
Organisations should weigh up the time taken to manage the sponsorship against the potential benefits.

Do not enter a partnership with a sponsor if their practices conflict with NHS aims and objectives or bring the hospital or the NHS into disrepute, nor any products or services associated with unhealthy lifestyles
Advertising space

Selling advertising space – for example, on the back of hospital appointment cards, on plasma screens or in other NHS-owned spaces – is a straightforward transaction. However, the public will make assumptions about the transaction and so consideration should be given to the following:
Who will see this advertising, and what message does it communicate about the relationship of the NHS to the advertiser?
Have you compared the costs (time, resources etc.) of selling advertising space to the benefits? Are the benefits sufficient to justify the risks?
Do you risk losing control of the process by working with a third-party?

A written contract must be put in place and you should consider excluding certain types of advertiser from this (e.g. tobacco, alcohol, ‘no win, no fee' solicitors, personal injury lawyers and claims management companies)
Advertising and Sponsorship Rates
We have sponsorship and advertising packages and we are also able to offer bespoke packages to meet requirements.
Please call the Communications and engagement team to discuss these options.
Principles and controls for advertising and sponsorship

MSEFT is not opposed in principle to accepting sponsorship for services, facilities or events, displaying or running ‘paid for' advertisements within the hospitals or Trust publications, if it is deemed to benefit the Trust.

Advertising displayed anywhere in the hospitals and in any Trust publications will reflect our core values and objectives. The look and feel of advertisements from any source – be that a private individual or large corporate company – will be professional and sympathetic to the caring environment.
Care needs to be taken when considering advertising services from companies in competition with the services MSEFT provides.

The Trust does not therefore take a ‘white listing' approach (which is when permitted advertising is defined) but rather follows a ‘black listing' approach (which is when the basic assumption is that advertising is permitted unless it falls into a number of prohibited categories, as defined in the chart in section 5.4).

The policy for advertising and sponsorship within the Trust includes advertisements displayed in; public areas (including maps and notice boards), within patient information, all published literature (including newsletters), display stands, bedside TV, plasma screens, website, exhibitions and all relevant marketing collateral (including posters, leaflets, giveaways, filming).
Authorisation
All enquiries regarding advertising or sponsorship must be referred to and authorised by the Associate Director of communications and engagement.

All contracts for advertising and sponsorship will be managed centrally by the Chief finance officer to ensure that the best terms are negotiated, that Standing Financial Instructions (SFIs) are not breached and ensure continuity and consistency.

The Associate Director of communications and engagement will review, approve, reject or sign off all advertising copy before any material is sent for printing or before any advertisement is displayed in any part of the hospital.
All advertising and sponsorship generated income is payable to the Trust via an income stream established within the communications budget code.

In all circumstances the Associate Director of communications and engagement retains the right to reject any advertisement or editorial relating to an advertisement. Where departments are approached directly for sponsorship and advertising purposes or where they are holding an event which requires sponsorship these principles still apply and the department must inform the communications and engagement department before approaching organisations. It may be necessary to request references from existing clients.
Prohibited products, services and advertisers

Third party advertisements and links to websites where goods and services are advertised does not mean the Trust endorses or recommends the advertiser's goods or services. Nor is the Trust responsible for the quality or reliability of the product or services offered but it will never knowingly allow sponsorship or advertising which is untrue or fraudulent.

The Trust has a highly-valued reputation as a provider of safe, sustainable, quality and professional care. The Trust's reputation and core values must not be compromised or put at risk by association with third party organisations advertisements or sponsorship.

For this reason, there are specific categories of products and services which may not be promoted, sponsored or advertised that could bring the trust or the NHS into disrepute, nor will any be accepted which promote products or services associated with unhealthy lifestyles.

table_items.text: Types of organisations refused advertising / sponsorship

Personal injury lawyers Claims management companies Specific ‘no win, no fee' companies Anti- governmental/political organisations Manufacturers of tobacco products Manufacturers of alcohol products Bookmakers and gambling organisations Pornography/adult industries Funeral directors (except for bereavement literature) Infant formula milk Manufacturers of firearms or other weaponry
The Trust emphasises that advertising or association with any of the listed suppliers, manufacturers or organisations is not permitted, nor with any companies associated with them.
Unrecognised health organisations who carry out plastic surgery Unestablished products e.g. quick fix diet remedies, complementary and therapies
The Trust emphasises that advertising or association with any unrecognised organisations is not permitted.

data.text: Other categories that will require careful consideration before acceptance for sponsorship or advertising includes; public sector organisations, private sector organisations in competition with the Trust.
In addition, any advertising or sponsorship which expresses a negative view of the NHS will not be accepted.
Advertising codes of practice and content
All advertising will adhere to the codes of practice issued by the independent regulator, the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA). These state that all advertisements must be:
Legal, decent, honest and truthful to the consumer society;
Prepared with a sense of responsibility; and
In line with the principles of fair competition generally accepted in business.

The Trust holds an equally open approach to styles of advertising, but advertisers must recognise that NHS organisations cannot permit advertising which contains sexual, adult content or which appears to promote or give undue publicity to, illegal or behaviours that are contrary to the healthy lifestyle promoted by the NHS.
No advertisements should discriminate or compromise the Equality and Human Rights policy for the Trust.
Promotion in public areas General advertising Trust-wide

This could include advertisements on noticeboards, flyers, adverts on the website or staff intranet. When the Trust is approached on general advertising issues, these must be discussed with the Associate Director of communications and engagement.
Posters and notices in staff only areas

These can be displayed at the discretion of the Associate Director of communications and engagement and the ward or department manager. All information displayed, however, must comply with the rules listed above. Notice boards, posters, tray adverts – public view areas

Posters and other notices should not be placed on walls or corridors around the hospital sites and should only be placed on established notice boards around the Trust. Posters and notices will be removed if not displayed in authorised or appropriate areas, or where they may cause damage to Trust property.
Posters must be removed following the event or when the information is no longer relevant. All Trust produced posters must comply with the Trust's branding and style guidelines.
Branding and style guidelines can be found on the intranet or by contacting the communications and engagement department at mse.communications@nhs.net.

There are a number of noticeboards in public areas of the hospitals. Some of these noticeboards are designated for use by unions such as Unison and Royal College of Nursing, some are used for staff communications such as benefits, Trust news or volunteer news.

There are ward/department boards on each ward and patient safety boards. The nursing directorate provides packs for each board. The ward or department manager is responsible for ensuring content is periodically reviewed and changed to reflect their department's activities.

Advertised noticeboards by third party companies may be displayed as part of the Trust's advertising and sponsorship packages they donate to. In this way any income generated can be used to benefit the whole Trust. This will be arranged and administered by the communications and engagement department.
Patient information leaflets

This policy only covers the commercial sponsorship and advertising aspects of patient information materials (including the use within the Trust of materials used by third party organisations). All other aspects of the development or approval of patient information materials should be undertaken in accordance with the MSEPO- 21059 Patient information leaflet policy.
Disclaimer notice
Acceptance of any advertising or sponsorship from a third party is not an endorsement or recommendation from the Trust for the advertiser's products or services.
The Trust is not responsible for the quality or reliability of the products or services offered, but is will never knowingly allow sponsorship or advertising which is untrue or fraudulent.

All advertising material should include the following disclaimer; Whilst every effort has been made to ensure the accuracy of advertisements, MSEFT cannot accept liability for any errors or omissions. The Trust does not accept responsibility for any claims made by advertisers and their inclusion in this leaflet/publication should not be taken as an endorsement by the Trust.
Exceptions
Any exceptions to the conditions or terms of this policy will be at the discretion of the Associate Director of communications and engagement.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Compliance with the policy – materials, health and safety
Approval of contracts (breaches of policy must be reported

data.text: Where contracts are in place or developed for advertising or display materials on Trust premises (e.g. site maps) then these standards will also apply to these display materials. They should be applied as part of the next available contract review.

All such advertising and display materials should be compliant with this policy within two years of ratification of this policy, except with the explicit agreement of the management executive (for example, where there is significant clinical, financial, corporate or other risk in relation to an existing contract that extends beyond this date). There may be legitimate circumstances where advertising is in place that does not meet the standards set out in this policy. This includes advertising that has been agreed prior to the introduction of this policy where it is not in the best interests of the trust to withdraw from the advertising ahead of an appropriate contract review.
Where a member of staff identifies any advertising that is not compliant with this policy then this should be reported to the head of communications and engagement.

Where non-compliant advertising has been approved by a department or directorate without reference to this policy then the relevant senior manager will agree an appropriate course of action with the Division/ associate director.
All such contraventions must be reported to the executive team at least annually as part of monitoring compliance with this policy.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Heads of Communication, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local communications guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Heads of Communication of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 1)
